bGRCAx-w3.memHandModelNotes: Home range size of 0.26 acres (Schoener 1968). # Mean home range size of 0.26 acres (Brewer 1955).  Mean Home Range .26acres=1052 sq meters =~ 33 m.  Hoffman (2001, http://www.ias.unt.edu/llela/documents/hoffman.pdf) thesis contains literature review of multiple papers looking at riparian widths and avian communities, general 100m widths supported higher densities for edge spp. Peak & Thompson (2006) found that gray catbird densities were highest in narrow forest riparian strips of 55-95m and had a negetive correlation with increased width.  Applied 120m Edge buffer. Amy Silvano 27nov06

bGRCAx-s2.memHandModelNotes: Home range size of 0.26 acres (Schoener 1968). # Mean home range size of 0.26 acres (Brewer 1955).  Mean Home Range .26acres=1052 sq meters =~ 33 m.  Hoffman (2001, http://www.ias.unt.edu/llela/documents/hoffman.pdf) thesis contains literature review of multiple papers looking at riparian widths and avian communities, general 100m widths supported higher densities for edge spp. Peak & Thompson (2006) found that gray catbird densities were highest in narrow forest riparian strips of 55-95m and had a negetive correlation with increased width.  Applied 120m Edge buffer. Amy Silvano 27nov06

habitat_description:
Gray catbirds inhabit dense shrubby areas in a variety of habitats, including shrubby swamps, thickets along the edges of woods, roads, or streams, overgrown fields, hedgerows, wooded residential areas, vine tangles, abandoned home sites, and high elevation balds (Stupka 1963, Fussell 1994, Kaufman 1996).  They are most abundant in shrub successional habitats and commonly found in damp areas (Cimprich & Moore 1995, Nicholson 1997).  They may, however, avoid dense forests and are generally uncommon in conifers but will be found in pine plantations (Cimprich & Moore 1995, GA-GAP 2003). 

Gray Catbird nests are dense thickets, briars, vine tangles, shrubs, and low trees, typically 1-3 m above ground (Harrison 1979). 

In the western U.S., Gray Catbirds occur at low elevation and in riparian thickets.  In the Southwest specifically, Gray Catbirds prefer dense shrublands, dense riparian thickets, and forested areas with thick undergrowth (Utah Conservation Data Center). A combination of dense vegetation and "ledge" situations are the ideal habitat for this species.  Coniferous forests are avoided but aspen groves are used (Johnsgard 1986, Andrews and Righter 1992).  

Winter habitat is similar to breeding habitat but they are more closely associated with water, although not exclusively associated with it (Cimprich and Moore 1995).  N. Tarr, 29July2010.
